intro: Bryanthus breweri, commonly known as the Brewer's bryanthus, is a small, flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
